Service Description: Service Design: Users text "SHOUT" to 85258 to initiate a conversation. The service operates 24/7, providing round-the-clock coverage.

Therapeutic Model: The intervention is structured to move the texter from a "hot moment" of high distress to a "cool calm." Trained volunteers, supported by clinical supervisors, utilize active listening and planning techniques to help the user reach a safe state.

the primary clinical hub for substance misuse in Harlow, operating from Unit 55 in The Harvey Centre.   

Access: The service prioritizes low-barrier access through drop-in assessment times (Mon-Thurs: 9:30am–12pm & 1pm–4pm), allowing individuals to seek help at the moment of motivation.   

Harm Reduction: The centre provides critical public health interventions, including a needle and syringe provision room to prevent blood-borne viruses, steroid packs, and Naloxone dispensing and training to prevent opiate overdose deaths.   

Treatment Pathways: For opiate users, Open Road works in partnership with Essex STaRS at the Princess Alexandra Hospital (Derwent Centre), ensuring medical oversight for substitution therapy.   

Holistic Support: Beyond medical treatment, the service offers one-to-one sessions, structured recovery programs, and the M-PACT program (Moving Parents and Children Together), which addresses the intergenerational impact of addiction
Support groups specifically for the families and friends of people with alcohol problems

This service operates at the intersection of criminal justice and health, supporting adults (18+) involved in the justice system who have substance use needs.

Mechanism: It utilizes Conditional Cautions and Community Resolution appointments to divert individuals from custody into treatment.   

Social Inclusion: A key component is the "Social Inclusion" element, which is open to self-referral and focuses on connecting users with meaningful community activities to break the cycle of reoffending.

Service: Essex Young People’s Drug and Alcohol Service (EYPDAS)
Service Description:
Co-located with Open Road, EYPDAS offers age-appropriate interventions for those under 25. This service acknowledges that youth addiction requires a different pedagogical and therapeutic approach.   

Interventions: Support includes one-to-one counseling, telephone support, and the "Recovery Pathway Group," a 6-week online course designed to educate young people on triggers and coping strategies.   

Education Link: The service delivers PSHE+ group work in schools, focusing on early intervention and the risks of emerging trends like illicit vaping.
online meetings to Building Motivation, Coping with Urges, Managing Thoughts/Feelings, and Living a Balanced Life

the lead provider for West Essex (Harlow, Epping, Uttlesford).

Counselling: They offer a free, confidential counseling service (up to 6 sessions) to help carers manage the emotional toll of their role.   

Grants: They facilitate "Time 4 You" grants, providing financial aid for carers to take a break or pursue a hobby.   

Support Groups: A Harlow support group meets at the Great Parndon Community Centre on the 2nd Tuesday of every month (10:30 am – 12:30 pm), providing peer connection.   

Day Care: They operate day care services that provide a safe environment for the cared-for person, granting the carer essential respite.

While Carers First is the lead for Mid/South Essex, they provide extensive online resources and the "Caring Confidently" training course, which helps carers build resilience and knowledge, accessible to all in the wider region.
Local wellbeing groups, counselling, and grants for adult family carers

Recognizing that many carers cannot leave their homes, Mobilise offers a "digital-first" support system.

Offerings: An online hub with guides on benefits (e.g., Carer's Allowance), "cuppas" (scheduled online chats), and coaching calls. This model ensures support is accessible regardless of mobility or time constraints.

offers a specialized respite model. Rather than removing the cared-for person to a facility, they provide one-to-one support in the home or community for adults with mental health needs or dementia. This allows the carer to leave the house with peace of mind.
Specialist rehabilitation and social support for both survivors and their carers
Peer support for both sufferers and their carers
Monthly meetings and connection for parents and carers of neurodiverse individuals in Harlow
initiated or planned suicide attempt
For urgent mental health help and crisis support
directory of mental and emotional health services including all kinds of abuse, children’s mental health, bereavement support, support groups and activities

Vita Health Group delivers the NHS Talking Therapies service (formerly IAPT) for West Essex. This service represents a significant shift towards patient autonomy through its "self-referral" model.

Eligibility: The service is open to anyone aged 16+ registered with a GP in Harlow, Uttlesford, or Epping Forest.   

Referral Pathways: The traditional barrier of requiring a GP referral has been removed. Patients can refer themselves via:

Telephone: A direct line (0333 015 2966) operates with extended hours (Mon–Thurs 8am–8pm, Fri 9am–5pm) to accommodate working adults.   

Digital Assistant: An automated tool named "Limbic" on their website guides users through a clinical assessment to streamline intake.   

Physical Drop-in: To bridge the digital divide, a drop-in service is hosted at Harlow Library on the last Tuesday of every month (12:30 pm – 2:30 pm). This ensures that those without digital access or confidence can still enter the therapeutic pathway.   

Interventions: The service offers a broad clinical menu, including Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT), Interpersonal Therapy (IPT), Counselling for Depression, and specialized pathways for those whose mental health is impacted by long-term physical conditions.
Eligibility: The service is open to anyone aged 16+ registered with a GP in Harlow, Uttlesford, or Epping Forest.

Addressing the critical issue of male suicide and the cultural stigma surrounding male mental health, Andy’s Man Club operates a strict but effective peer-support model.

Operations: The group meets every Monday at 7:00 pm (excluding Bank Holidays) at the Latton Bush Centre.   

Protocol: The doors open at 18:45 to allow for settling in. The meetings are free, confidential, and require no booking or referral.   

Philosophy: The group is explicitly non-clinical and "judgement-free," designed to provide a space where men can discuss the "storms" in their lives without pressure. The "no obligation to speak" rule is a critical design feature, lowering the anxiety threshold for new attendees.
Telephone: A direct line (0333 015 2966) operates with extended hours (Mon–Thurs 8am–8pm, Fri 9am–5pm) to accommodate working adults.

Focusing on mental health, Employ-Ability uses the Individual Placement and Support (IPS) model.

Job Retention: They offer a specific service for those struggling to maintain employment due to mental ill health, negotiating "reasonable adjustments" with employers.   

IPS-Y: A pilot program specifically targeting 14-18-year-olds in West Essex, bridging the gap between education and employment for vulnerable youth.

Physical Drop-in: To bridge the digital divide, a drop-in service is hosted at Harlow Library on the last Tuesday of every month (12:30 pm – 2:30 pm). This ensures that those without digital access or confidence can still enter the therapeutic pathway.

Located at "The Bungalow" in the Latton Bush Centre, this organization offers a holistic, activity-based approach to mental wellness. It operates daily, providing a schedule that integrates social support with therapeutic activities.   

Activity Schedule: The provision is diverse, including "Social Wellbeing Groups" (Mon/Wed/Fri 11am-2:30pm), "Mindful Gardening" (Tue 10am-12:30pm), and relaxation sessions for carers (Thu 11am-12pm).   

Holistic Therapies: In addition to social groups, they offer sound healing (Gong Baths) and Reiki, recognizing the somatic aspects of mental distress.   

Economic Accessibility: While some treatments have a charge, many activities are free or donation-based, ensuring the service remains accessible to low-income residents.

Interventions: The service offers a broad clinical menu, including Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT), Interpersonal Therapy (IPT), Counselling for Depression, and specialized pathways for those whose mental health is impacted by long-term physical conditions.

Access Protocol: Access is controlled through a registration process. Users must complete a form or scan a QR code to register, after which a member of the Night Owls team conducts a call-back within 24 hours. This triage step is crucial for risk assessment and ensures the service is appropriate for the user. Once registered, users are provided with a dedicated number to call at will during operating hours.

Physical Sanctuary: Uniquely, registered users can access "Sanctuary Spaces" for face-to-face support between 4:00 pm and 11:00 pm. This provision acknowledges that for many in crisis, the physical presence of a compassionate listener is more effective than remote communication. The Sanctuary team is trained to be non-judgmental and can escalate cases to the Crisis team if urgent clinical intervention is required

This organization focuses on practical empowerment. They provide "Spectrum Support Packs" containing sensory tools (ear defenders, weighted pads) and visual aids (Now/Next boards), which are heavily subsidized or funded by grants. Their "Spectrum University" offers online training to help families and professionals understand neurodiversity through a neuro-affirming lens.

Based in the Latton Bush Centre, PACT serves as a primary hub for the neurodiverse community.

Open Access: They explicitly state that no formal diagnosis is required to access their services, ensuring immediate support for families in limbo.   

Activities: The charity runs age-stratified social clubs, including "Wild & Wacky" soft play, "Gamer’s Cage" for teens, and "Art Empower" workshops.   

Parent Support: "Parent/Carer Connect" sessions and "Walk and Talk" events provide a peer support network, reducing the isolation often felt by SEND families.   

Advocacy: Their "Signpost" service assists with the complexities of Education, Health and Care Plans (EHCPs) and benefits, leveraging the "lived experience" of their staff
A social group for neurodivergent adults to meet in Harlow Town Park

operates across Essex to support adults with learning disabilities and autism into sustainable employment.

Methodology: They utilize "vocational profiling" to match individual skills to employer needs and provide job coaching and travel training to ensure long-term retention.

An innovative collaboration between Harlow Amateur Boxing Club and Active Essex provides free boxing lessons specifically for neurodivergent individuals.

Schedule: Saturdays at 11:00 am – 12:00 pm at the club on Momples Road.   

Therapeutic Value: The program uses non-contact boxing to improve fitness, focus, memory, and coordination, demonstrating the therapeutic potential of sport.

This charity provides the technical and legal scaffolding for families navigating the SEND system.

Educational Advocacy: They offer expert guidance on securing Education, Health and Care Plans (EHCPs), supporting families through the drafting process, annual reviews, and even tribunals.   

Benefit Support: They assist with the complex applications for Disability Living Allowance (DLA) and Personal Independence Payment (PIP), often hosting online clinics to guide parents through the forms.   

Social Clubs: They run "Saturday Activity Clubs" (currently in Chelmsford) that are accessible to Harlow families, providing a safe space for SEND children and their siblings.
Clinical resources for neurodiversity and speech therapy

Service: Self-referral to Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy in West Essex
Service Description: Direct access to NHS physiotherapy for bone, joint, or muscle problems without needing a GP referral
Online clinical resources and guidance specifically for managing various MSK conditions
County-wide partnership promoting local sport, physical activity, and inclusive fitness tailored to your lifestyle
Online hub providing instructor-led exercise videos for different fitness levels and physical conditions

This NHS service represents a progressive approach to women's health. It supports those experiencing pelvic health issues (incontinence, prolapse) during pregnancy and up to 12 months postpartum.

Access: Uniquely, it offers a self-referral pathway via an online form, removing the need for a GP appointment and empowering women to seek help directly.

(Treehouse Family Hub) The Treehouse Family Hub (Parnall Road) is the central nerve centre for family services in Harlow.   

Services: It offers health visiting, infant feeding support, school nursing, and developmental checks.   

Delivery Sites: Services are also delivered at satellite sites like The Meadows and Potter Street to ensure neighborhood-level access.   

Activity: The hub hosts "Healthy Family Drop-ins" and specialized sessions like "Sparkles" for SEND children.
Support for vulnerable children and families dealing with complex issues
Advice and activity clubs for families with children who have special needs

Home-Start supports families with children under 5 who are facing difficulties such as isolation, mental health issues, or multiple births.

Home Visiting: Trained volunteers visit families in their own homes to provide practical and emotional support.   

Groups: They run "Family Groups" and "Fitness and Fun" sessions to encourage parent-child bonding and physical activity.   

Access: Families can self-refer via the website or telephone (01245 847410)
Free developmental activities that support literacy and socialization.
Support for trans-gender children and their families

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description:
Located in the town centre, this is the primary hub for independent advice.

Law Clinic: A standout service is the Law Clinic, which offers free 30-minute telephone appointments with volunteer solicitors. This covers family, employment, and immigration law, providing access to justice for those unable to afford private counsel.

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description:
Located at Beaufort House (Crown Gate), the Jobcentre manages Universal Credit claims and employment support. It acts as a referral node, connecting claimants with partners like Employ-Ability for specialized support.   

Opening Hours: Mon-Fri, 9:00 am – 5:00 pm (Wednesdays open at 10:00 am).

Service Description: Support for training, CVs, and interviews

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Education courses; many are free for those on benefits

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Peabody provides housing-related support to prevent homelessness before it occurs. Their "floating support" officers visit residents in their homes to assist with tenancy management, rent arrears, and budgeting. They also hold drop-in sessions at locations like Jobcentre Plus

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Moves individuals from the streets into sustainable housing while addressing the health and social barriers that caused the homelessness

Service Description:
ital for Harlow’s migrant and refugee population.

Casework: They provide one-to-one support for housing, benefits, and school applications.   

Social Integration: They run ESOL (English) classes and the "Women's Health Club" (Tuesdays 11am-1pm at Latton Bush), creating safe spaces for new arrivals to build networks.

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: In response to energy poverty, Harlow Council has designated venues like Harlow Playhouse and local libraries as "Warm Spaces." These locations offer heat, seating, and sometimes hot drinks, providing a non-stigmatizing refuge during winter months.

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Emergency food parcels in Harlow Town Centre

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Emergency supplies and community support

Category: Work, Money & Housing and Food Banks
Service Description: Access to fresh surplus food (fruit, veg, bread) donated by local supermarkets
Address: Thursdays 5:30 PM – 8:00 PM at St Paul’s Church, College Square, CM20 1LP

Service Description: Single point of access for victims of domestic abuse to find support and refuge
Specialist domestic abuse charity providing housing, safety planning, and outreach
Confidential support and information for women experiencing domestic violence and their children
Specialist advice and assistance for those facing or in a forced marriage
Honour-based abuse helpline
Tailored domestic abuse support specifically for the LGBTQ+ community
Structured intervention aimed at helping individuals who have committed domestic abuse to change their behaviour and promote safety for survivors

Service Description: Rapid response service operates 08:00–20:00, 7 days a week. It deploys a paramedic and therapist to uninjured fallers in their homes, conducting immediate assessments to prevent unnecessary hospital admissions.

Service: Community Falls Strength and Balance Exercise Service
Service Description: Run by NELFT, this service provides 12-week exercise programs designed to improve stability in older adults, addressing the root cause of falls.

Service Description: Door-to-door transport for those with mobility needs

Service Description: Provides free NHS health checks for eligible residents aged 40–74 and lifestyle assessments

Service Description: List of local support for older people, including help to live independently, dementia and memory‑support services, day centres, safety checks at home, befriending to reduce loneliness, mobility equipment like wheelchairs, and other health, wellbeing and social care advice

Service Description:
this project provides the hardware and skills necessary for modern life.

Provision: They distribute donated devices and SIM cards with data to those in need.   

Education: "Digital Skills Hubs" at Harlow Town Library and Tye Green Library offer training on using the NHS app, setting up email, and online safety.   

Support: Volunteer "Tech Advisors" are available to troubleshoot specific issues.

Category: Age Related Needs (Mobility, Lifestyle, Care, Community)
Service Description:
Rainbow Services is a cornerstone of Harlow's voluntary sector.

Community Hub: Located in the Harvey Centre and Wych Elm, this hub acts as a physical "front door" for crisis support, volunteering information, and signposting.   

Community Builder: This project actively supports residents in setting up their own social groups, shifting the dynamic from "service delivery" to "community empowerment".   

Social Prescribing: They manage the "My Health Matters" project, connecting residents with non-clinical support for issues like loneliness.

Category: Age Related Needs (Mobility, Lifestyle, Care, Community)
Service Description:
For temporary mobility needs, the Red Cross in Harlow provides a wheelchair hire service.

Cost: Standard hire is £22 per week, with a delivery/collection fee of £30.   

Access: Assistance is available for those unable to pay, and no GP referral is required, ensuring rapid deployment for post-operative recovery or end-of-life care
List of services for physical/sensory disabilities, long-term conditions, and SEND, including equipment like wheelchairs, everyday living and benefits advice

Rapid response service operates 08:00–20:00, 7 days a week. It deploys a paramedic and therapist to uninjured fallers in their homes, conducting immediate assessments to prevent unnecessary hospital admissions.
Advice and equipment directories for staying physically independent at home

For temporary mobility needs, the Red Cross in Harlow provides a wheelchair hire service.

Cost: Standard hire is £22 per week, with a delivery/collection fee of £30.   

Access: Assistance is available for those unable to pay, and no GP referral is required, ensuring rapid deployment for post-operative recovery or end-of-life care
specializes in leisure and social opportunities for people with disabilities

Located on the River Stort, CanalAbility offers a unique accessible leisure experience.

Infrastructure: They operate purpose-built broad beam boats ("Stort Daybreak" and "Stort Challenger") equipped with lifts, ramps, and accessible toilets.   

Inclusivity: The design allows wheelchair users and those with complex disabilities to actively participate in steering the boat and operating locks, promoting agency and independence.
The town's primary leisure centre is equipped with "wet rooms" and pool hoists, enabling fully accessible swimming for residents with physical disabilities.
Clinical resources for neurodiversity and speech therapy
Help with meals, shopping, home adaptations, and technology for independent living
Specialist rehabilitation and social support
online one-to-one and group therapy for adults with neurological conditions (e.g., brain injury). It focuses on speech, memory, and fatigue management.
Weekly meetings and specialist advice
Support, grants, and information

Online or telephone assessment for any needs

Hot meals delivery, regular phone calls, moving furniture, essential home tasks to prepare the home for your return, installation of key safe for carers/emergency services, install personal alarms or assistive tech

Situated in the Walled Garden of Harlow Town Park, this initiative addresses male isolation through shared practical tasks.

Schedule: Open every Tuesday (10:00 am – 4:00 pm).   

Concept: Men work on woodwork and repair projects "shoulder to shoulder," a dynamic proven to facilitate conversation and mental well-being more effectively than face-to-face therapy for many men.

Community networking group connecting local residents with local support and activities

The "Find Your Active" campaign connects residents with local sports. A flagship initiative, Essex Pedal Power, distributes free bikes to eligible residents in Harlow to combat transport poverty and encourage physical activity

in the Walled Garden, this therapeutic gardening group meets on Mondays (1:00 pm – 3:00 pm). It provides a calm, sensory-rich environment suitable for those with dementia or mental health needs.
